discourse_list.title: [Tutorial] Increase the Surplus Buffer using the `lerp` Module

content.content: Hi Everyone, Presently, we have determined to burn approximately x% (eg. 25%) of accumulated protocol revenues accruing to the surplus buffer via FLAP auctions up until a new maximum (eg. 60M DAI). In order to do this we have set a target in the future based on historical revenues in which to slowly increase the surplus buffer up to the new maximum. For example, the protocol is bringing in 400k DAI per day. We want to increase the buffer every day by 300k DAI so that 100k gets auctioned off. This will take ~100 days at the current rate. This is where the lerp module comes in.  The Lerp Module  The lerp module is the smart contract that calculates and executes the ability for the surplus buffer (as well as any other realistic use case) to increase at a pre-determined rate. To use it is quite simple.   Simply navigate to this contract on etherscan. Additional lerp contract can be found here.   Connect your wallet of choice via Web3.   Once connected, expand the “5. tall” category and click “write”.   Finish by executing the transaction.   Voila! The surplus buffer will now have increased based on the calculation set within its code.    Conclusion  I created this simple tutorial mainly as a searchable reference point for community members wishing to maintain and contribute to helping the protocol. Please let me know if you have any feedback. I hope you find this useful. Thanks!
Freaking legend for typing this up. Idk why that never occurred to me, thank you!
What incentives lead someone to execute this function?
Excellent initiative. But what do I do if I want to reduce the buffer, not increase it. It will need to go both ways eventually
I think you need to simply math. People see 31 mill one day then 31.8 next. After 31 reached
Thanks for sharing. I’m genuinely interested as to why it has to be done manually; sounds like a temporary solution…?!
Well a bot could lerp it but someone still has to pay that gas.
I believe it is a temporary solution, not a long term for now 50 days. To be honest I am less and less convinced by the burner. It is nice but I don’t think it does a lot on the price.

alexis:  I am less and less convinced by the burner. It is nice but I don’t think it does a lot on the price.   I don’t understand. Demand is demand. Ok, it’s not the burning per se, it’s the buying first. But still, there’s a net effect on supply/demand that has the same impact as in any other market.

It’s also psychological. MKR price didn’t move for months until the 25% burn was planned. Could be a coincidence but people knowing that there will be sustained buy pressure creates market confidence.

If we decrease the SF we will boost the dai that will be more efficient than 3% a year. We can pay CU that would be probably more efficient than a 3% a year. We can finance projects (euro dai) that should be more efficient than 3% a year. Burning at 3% is being as greedy as Picsou
What about security? There has to be some mechanism that keeps MKR price broadly in line with Dai supply or we are in for a world of trouble.
Agree but that is different than burning

I’d vastly prefer we deploy earnings for expansion into other products or to scale our RWA and crypto products faster. Not sure that’s going to happen. So burn is better than nothing. But I’d also rather fill the SB first.

In this degen economy you need some sort of price appreciation for the token or people won’t buy it, silly as it sounds. We were vastly undervalued for the last year mainly because we didn’t have direct incentives or burning enabled (in my opinion). This can create a security risk if it’s cheap for an attacker to accumulate tokens.
I am not against buying back, but I think there is some timing and price opportunities. The burner missed them mainly every time.
What would you suggest? Put the Dai in a fund for a burn, timing to be decided by governance?
Define a buying price or a range, that can be a solution. Eventually increasing the price with the lerp.

My suggestion is to build a segregated Dai buffer to be used for slowing down the rate of flops (minting MKR).  While not guaranteed, MKR might tend to be cheaper when the protocol is minting MKR.  Proposed Mechanism to Dampen MKR Mint/Burn

I like this approach. So long as MKR keeps going up in line with stability fees or better, no burns. If the ratio drops, switch it on. However there might need to be some provision in case MKR dropped for more fundamental reasons, rather than just market inefficiency.
